title: 112_hr3117
content: The Act is titled the "Permanent Electronic Duck Stamp Act of 2012" and includes definitions. The "Permanent Electronic Duck Stamp Act of 2012" defines terms such as "actual stamp" as a paper Federal migratory-bird hunting stamp, "automated licensing system" as an electronic system for issuing licenses, and "electronic stamp" as a digital version of the actual stamp. The term "electronic stamp" refers to a unique identifier issued to individuals, printed on paper or produced electronically with the same indicators as a State endorsement. It is issued through a State automated licensing system authorized by the Secretary of the Interior and must be compatible with the State's hunting licensing system. The Secretary may authorize States to issue electronic stamps under this Act, in consultation with State management agencies. The Secretary may authorize States to issue electronic stamps under this Act after receiving and approving an application from the State. The application must include details such as the format of the electronic stamp, fees charged, accounting process for transferring funds to the Secretary, transmission of customer data, and delivery of actual stamps. The Secretary can determine the number of new States per year to participate in the program. The State must transfer required data to the Secretary, transmit electronic stamp customer data, deliver actual stamps, issue duplicate electronic stamps, and provide other necessary information. The Secretary will publish deadlines, eligibility requirements, and selection criteria for applications. State obligations and authorities include transferring data to the Secretary, transmitting electronic stamp customer data, delivering actual stamps, issuing duplicate electronic stamps, and providing necessary information. The Secretary will establish deadlines, eligibility requirements, and selection criteria for applications. The Secretary requires states to deliver actual stamps to individuals who purchase electronic stamps, collect and submit customer information and revenue to the Secretary, including buyer details and stamp values. Submission must be timely as per the agreement. The Secretary mandates states to submit customer information and revenue for electronic stamp sales promptly as per the agreement. States authorized to issue electronic stamps can charge a fee to cover issuance costs, including delivery. Additionally, states can issue duplicate electronic stamps for lost or damaged ones, and they cannot compel individuals to purchase a state hunting license. Electronic stamps can be replaced if lost or damaged. States cannot require the purchase of a hunting license to issue an electronic stamp. SEC. 6. ELECTRONIC STAMP REQUIREMENTS; RECOGNITION OF ELECTRONIC STAMP. The Secretary shall require an electronic stamp issued by a State to have the same format as any other license and specify identifying features of the licensee. The electronic stamp bestows the same privileges as an actual stamp, is recognized nationally, and authorizes hunting in other States. It is valid for a period agreed upon by the State and the Secretary, not exceeding 45 days. The authority of a State to issue electronic stamps under this Act may be terminated by the Secretary if the State violates the terms approved by the Secretary, or by the State itself with written notice to the Secretary.
